title: Behavioral Interview Prep
description: STAR method stories and soft skills questions

cards.front: What is the STAR method?
cards.back: Situation: Set the context. Task: Describe your responsibility. Action: Explain what YOU did (use 'I'). Result: Share outcomes with metrics. Keep 2-3 min, focus on Action (60%).
cards.summary: STAR: Situation, Task, Action, Result. Structure for answering behavioral questions, emphasizing your actions and their impact.

cards.front: Tell me about a challenging bug you fixed
cards.back: Structure: Describe the bug's impact → Your debugging process → Tools/techniques used → Root cause found → Fix implemented → Prevention measures added. Mention: Logs, profiler, breakpoints.
cards.summary: A memory leak caused performance issues. I used Instruments and breakpoints to identify and fix it by releasing the leaked object and adding automated testing.

cards.front: Describe a time you disagreed with a technical decision
cards.back: Show: 1) You understood the other perspective 2) Presented data/evidence for your view 3) Remained professional 4) Accepted outcome gracefully OR influenced change 5) What you learned.
cards.summary: I disagreed with a decision, understood the rationale, presented data to support my alternative, and remained professional, ultimately influencing the outcome/learning.

cards.front: How do you handle tight deadlines?
cards.back: Approach: 1) Prioritize ruthlessly (MVP) 2) Communicate early if at risk 3) Break into smaller deliverables 4) Ask for help/delegate 5) Manage scope. Example: Feature cut to meet launch.
cards.summary: Prioritize ruthlessly (MVP), communicate risks early, and break tasks into smaller deliverables.

cards.front: Tell me about a project you're proud of
cards.back: Include: Technical challenges overcome, your specific contributions, impact/metrics, what made it meaningful. Show passion but stay concise. Connect to company's work if possible.
cards.summary: Led a key feature overcoming X challenge, improving Y metric by Z%. Meaningful due to its impact on [user/company].

cards.front: How do you approach learning new technologies?
cards.back: Process: 1) Official docs/tutorials 2) Build small project 3) Read source code 4) Contribute or teach others. Examples: Recent tech learned, side projects, blog posts, conference talks.
cards.summary: Docs/tutorials, build a small project, then explore code and teach or contribute.

cards.front: Describe a time you mentored someone
cards.back: Cover: Who and context → Your teaching approach → Challenges faced → Their growth/outcome → What you learned. Even informal help counts: Code reviews, pair programming, onboarding.
cards.summary: I mentored a junior dev through code reviews, focusing on best practices and clear communication, leading to improved code quality and confidence.

cards.front: How do you handle code review feedback?
cards.back: Good answer: Welcome feedback, ask clarifying questions, discuss tradeoffs respectfully, don't take personally, learn from patterns. Mention: Times you changed approach based on review.
cards.summary: Welcome feedback, ask questions, discuss tradeoffs respectfully, and learn from the review.

cards.front: Tell me about a failure and what you learned
cards.back: Be genuine: Real failure with real impact → Your responsibility (no blame) → What went wrong → Concrete changes made → How it made you better. Shows self-awareness and growth.
cards.summary: I owned a failure, explained what went wrong, and detailed the changes I made to improve and grow from the experience.

cards.front: How do you prioritize when everything is urgent?
cards.back: Framework: 1) Clarify actual urgency with stakeholders 2) Impact vs effort matrix 3) Dependencies first 4) Communicate tradeoffs 5) Document decisions. Example story of tough prioritization.
cards.summary: Assess impact/effort, dependencies, and clarify urgency with stakeholders. Communicate tradeoffs and document decisions.

cards.front: Describe working with a difficult team member
cards.back: Focus on: Understanding their perspective, finding common ground, adapting your communication, maintaining professionalism, positive outcome. Never badmouth, show empathy.
cards.summary: Understand their view, find common ground, adapt communication, and stay professional for a positive resolution.

cards.front: Why are you interested in this company?
cards.back: Research: Product you admire, technical challenges, team/culture, growth opportunity. Be specific: 'I've used X feature and love how...' Connect your skills to their needs.
cards.summary: Admire your product/challenges. My skills in [skill] align with your needs and offer growth.

cards.front: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?
cards.back: Show: Ambition + realism + alignment with company. Options: Senior/Staff engineer, tech lead, architect, domain expert. Mention: Skills to develop, impact to make.
cards.summary: Growing into a senior role (tech lead/architect) leveraging my skills to contribute significantly to the company's goals.

cards.front: How do you stay current with iOS development?
cards.back: Sources: WWDC, Swift Evolution, iOS dev blogs (NSHipster, SwiftLee), Twitter/Mastodon, podcasts, conferences. Practice: Side projects, open source, beta testing new APIs.
cards.summary: WWDC, blogs, social media, and side projects. I learn from the community and apply new knowledge practically.

cards.front: Describe a time you improved a process
cards.back: Example areas: CI/CD setup, code review guidelines, documentation, testing practices, onboarding. Show: Identified problem → Proposed solution → Got buy-in → Implemented → Measured impact.
cards.summary: I streamlined code reviews by creating guidelines, leading to faster feedback and improved code quality.

cards.front: How do you handle ambiguous requirements?
cards.back: Approach: 1) Ask clarifying questions 2) Document assumptions 3) Build MVP for feedback 4) Iterate based on input. Show you're proactive, not paralyzed by ambiguity.
cards.summary: Ask clarifying questions, document assumptions, build an MVP for feedback, and iterate.

cards.front: Tell me about working with cross-functional teams
cards.back: Examples: Designers, PMs, backend, QA. Show: Clear communication, understanding their constraints, finding compromises, shared documentation, successful collaboration outcome.
cards.summary: Effective collaboration relies on clear communication, understanding roles, and finding compromises within cross-functional teams.

cards.front: How do you ensure code quality?
cards.back: Practices: Unit tests, code review, CI/CD, linting, documentation, pair programming. Mention: Coverage targets, review guidelines you follow, quality metrics you track.
cards.summary: I ensure code quality through unit testing, code reviews, CI/CD, linting, and documentation.

cards.front: Describe leading a technical initiative
cards.back: Cover: Problem identified → Built case for solving it → Planned approach → Coordinated team → Handled obstacles → Delivered results. Leadership doesn't require title.
cards.summary: I identified a problem, built a case, planned, coordinated a team, overcame obstacles, and delivered results, showing leadership.

cards.front: What questions do you have for us?
cards.back: Good questions: Team structure, technical challenges, how success is measured, growth opportunities, engineering culture, recent projects. Shows genuine interest and research.
cards.summary: Ask about team, challenges, success metrics, growth, culture, and recent projects.
